display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; vertical-align: top; overflow: hidden; max-height: 150px; max-width: 180px; width: 180px; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: Every branch, and thus every associated RC package and dev deploy, should be able to generate its own unique environment, specific to the branch

div.style: display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; vertical-align: top; overflow: hidden; max-height: 180px; max-width: 283px; width: 283px; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: To keep the management of the pipelines relatively simple, which will help maximize ROI, a team may find it beneficial to create one type of pipeline per repository.

div.style: display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; vertical-align: top; overflow: hidden; max-height: 160px; max-width: 350px; width: 350px; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.p: Getting packages and applications into the hands of those who will be using them early on is essential for remaining nimble and ensuring that the work being done meets requirements. This is why RC packages are automatically built for every branch. To prevent development/beta code from ever being released, most release pipelines should then enforce a gate that ensures no RC dependencies are in the artifacts.

div.style: display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; vertical-align: top; overflow: hidden; max-height: 160px; max-width: 426px; width: 426px; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.h1: Moving checks to the release pipeline:
div.p: To keep the build pipeline fast, which allows for code to be integrated faster, it may prove beneficial to move some long running checks to the release pipeline. If a check fails there, it could auto open a ticket so that the issue can be addressed quickly. Once the issue is addressed by merging the fix into master, this whole process will start again.

div.style: display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; vertical-align: top; overflow: hidden; max-height: 160px; max-width: 400px; width: 400px; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: It is perfectly reasonable to deploy production packages separate from production client changes, as client changes may have to go through more rigorous testing depending on the scope of the change (e.g. does it possibly require retraining users?). Typically, however, a client should exist in its own repository, away from service-like repositories, and thus it should have its own pipelines.
